content.html:
Via@feditips@mstdn.social

â€”-

If you like to share photos you might want to check out @pixelfed, an Instagram-style photo sharing network on the Fediverse.

You can find out more and sign up at:

pixelfed.org

PixelFed uses the same federation protocol as Mastodon, which means Mastodon users can follow people on PixelFed and vice versa. You can try following a PixelFed account right now such as @Iancylkowski or @JoseMel or @connyduck

You can use PixelFed through a web browser, and there are also free open Android apps like @PixelDroid and FediLab (@apps).

#Fediverse #FediTips #Instagram #Alternatives #PixelFed

content.html:
In reply to hacdias.com/2022/12/2â€¦

I completely understand; Iâ€™ll probably become a â€œ404â€ comment too after my time with micro.blog is up (unless thereâ€™s a way to make a 301 Moved note somewhere)

But I still believe in preserving for posterity. I have entire tweets replies that have been locked and deletedâ€“ saving comments to your blog keeps that ephemerality from spreading and you can at the very least see where the discussion went, even if the people who typed those words have moved on to some other digital domain.

ğŸ¤”âœğŸ¾ Iâ€™ve got an impending blog post expounding on this subject â€œcoming soonâ„¢â€

Itâ€™s important to note:

Mastodon =/= Fediverse; Fediverse == #Mastodon, #Pixelfed, #Write.as, #Micro.blog, #Pleroma, #Peertube, #Lemmy etc.

Thereâ€™s a whole breadth of components that plug into this ecosystem and each one has its own strengths and weaknesses. Its pretty easy to imagine journalists using more than one tool that can get the job done
